headline: NetApp, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a question about the buyback that you alluded to in your earlier comments.  To what extent might that be a response to what the stock did today and seemingly to be doing in the aftermarket? And philosophically, how opportunistic might you be willing
componenttext: Just a question about the buyback that you alluded to in your earlier comments.  To what extent might that be a response to what the stock did today and seemingly to be doing in the aftermarket? And philosophically, how opportunistic might you be willing to be, any context you can give us would be great.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Those are fair questions. For what it's worth that part of the script was written before today's performance. So we basically, we told you that we have the authorization from the Board last quarter when we did the buyback you know how much the authorizati
componenttext: Those are fair questions. For what it's worth that part of the script was written before today's performance. So we basically, we told you that we have the authorization from the Board last quarter when we did the buyback you know how much the authorization is and how much is left. We told you we would probably continue at that point now we are affirming that we're going to continue. We haven't decided on amount, the timing. We obviously don't know the share price yet but there's not a lot of other details I can give you. But indeed, if it's better to buy stock when it's down as opposed to up so it looks like it could be a good opportunity right now.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Moskowitz from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Moskowitz from JPMorgan.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: More of a technology question, Tom. I just want to get a sense of what you're seeing from customer interest in terms of ONTAP 8.1. What kind of benefits can you may be drive that could attract customers or retain customer interest if the macro issues were
componenttext: More of a technology question, Tom. I just want to get a sense of what you're seeing from customer interest in terms of ONTAP 8.1. What kind of benefits can you may be drive that could attract customers or retain customer interest if the macro issues were worse than other, or cost savings with ONTAP 8.1 that could really reserve your relevance and data center optimization?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the essence of ONTAP 8.1 is the first time we're going to broadly marry our enterprise data management software suite with clustering to basically bring that in scale. So and that's got applications in many dimensions, including obviously the
componenttext: Yes, I think the essence of ONTAP 8.1 is the first time we're going to broadly marry our enterprise data management software suite with clustering to basically bring that in scale. So and that's got applications in many dimensions, including obviously the obvious ones on a purely performance side and the scalability side and content repository side. But the thing that's especially unique about it is that we bring the data management suite and we are bringing it to enterprise customers and traditional business NetApp's and we're marrying that with 2 scale requesting and that's really a going to be the only true platform of its type that's targeted at the enterprise customer. So it's really a monetization of storage for the enterprise customer. Mostly enterprise applications are still running on applications that are 15 to 20 years old. So that is that really is the big push on this and so it will spill over to high-performance computing, it will spill over to high technical computing and a lot of the scalability boundary limits and things like that will be relaxed so make things easier to manage. So value proposition I think is clearly the ability to bring up, value proposition to a greater set of customers and a greater set of applications. For exiting customers, obviously, the manageability and the scalability and the performance and the ability to manage storage as a pool as oppose to individual box. I think we will have tremendous advantages from the complexity perspective or performance perspective. And really the ability to build a virtualized infrastructure, the ability to the broader storage pool to serve a big server that is capable of running multiple apps at the same time and manage security, manage performance, manage capacity, manage cost. So I think from that perspective, that's a generic value proposition whether the industry is up or the industry is down. I think what it will do is it will broaden the applicability of our storage efficiency technologies, our deduplication for primaries which we are still the only player to do that probably, the provisioning, the use of ATA drives. So what we'll be able to do is bring that storage value proposition, which I think will be particularly relevant to the downturn. It's really was the last time. I think the storage efficiency messaging really helped us a lot as the economic to what we are depressed overall my view is I think what I'll do is broadly applicability of the things that do have value in the downturn, which is primarily storage efficiency. But will also open up at least customers and to us that perhaps some markets are concerned about our scalability in the past. So is there anything specific about a downturn that would make this particularly applicable? No, just the ability to play storage efficiency more broadly. But absent that, I think this is a fundamentally different approach to enterprise storage and it's going to be a big departure from what customers have and really deliver what I think is unquestionably the biggest software feature set in the industry and bring that to enterprise app in scale.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Federal Government and channel services is the characterization that they've shelved the deals or they still in discussion or don't know. I'm just want to understand they pulled or tabled. And then related to that when I look at your guidance for this upc
componenttext: Federal Government and channel services is the characterization that they've shelved the deals or they still in discussion or don't know. I'm just want to understand they pulled or tabled. And then related to that when I look at your guidance for this upcoming quarter, it's a fairly wide range of 3% to 10% but if I took a midpoint. In the last 2 years, you've grown 8% and 9% sequentially so it's in that same neighborhood. My question is have you let yourself enough room here? Because it seems likely closely your assuming that the weak areas of federal and financial grow at normal seasonal trends. I'm just trying to reconcile that with your comments on uncertainty surrounding their current demand trends.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, nothing that we didn't have last year is that we have the deferreds  going at a reasonable rate that we didn't have a year ago and that will clearly help us in this particularly, on this particular dimension. As far as deals bill being shelved or wh
componenttext: Well, nothing that we didn't have last year is that we have the deferreds  going at a reasonable rate that we didn't have a year ago and that will clearly help us in this particularly, on this particular dimension. As far as deals bill being shelved or whatever, I'd say more so on the federal side than on the commercial side, including financial services. I don't think that any of them sat down and rearchitected and recrafted their budgets for the entire year and everybody has their budgets. I think people operating under the old rules and this was spending is being modulated as high levels when these things have to be signed off. So I'd say on the federal side, clearly, projects have been deferred. I'd say, on the U.S. side and particularly in the financial services sector, I think those are still in the delayed. And if things look a little, approve that type of.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from Chris Whitmore from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our last question comes from Chris Whitmore from Deutsche Bank.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: To follow up on Keith's question. I just wanted to ask about the impact cycles on customer spends. In other words, do you think you're seeing a pause in front of Romilly or a pause for evaluation of ONTAP 8.1 et cetera that's contributing to the pull back
componenttext: To follow up on Keith's question. I just wanted to ask about the impact cycles on customer spends. In other words, do you think you're seeing a pause in front of Romilly or a pause for evaluation of ONTAP 8.1 et cetera that's contributing to the pull back or do you think this is purely macro?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the server side, I don't think that the Intel refresh that has a big of an impact on our business. In some ways, you can't argue if it would be the opposite. I think the big server spend would be less on storage. I really don't know.  I never really se
componenttext: On the server side, I don't think that the Intel refresh that has a big of an impact on our business. In some ways, you can't argue if it would be the opposite. I think the big server spend would be less on storage. I really don't know.  I never really see the correlation there. What's interesting about our businesses is that the customer behavior is actually more driven by platform refreshes than there are software refreshes. So think about 8.1 is it's going to run on the platforms that we currently ship so if they make an investment on the platform today and then they can upgrade to 8.1, it isn't like the equipment is obsolete. So from that perspective, I'm not expecting that there's a big way for 8.1 to come along. I just don't see that. If 8.1 only ran on a platform, a new platform that only ran in 8.1 that would be a little different but I just don't think that's the case. So the server thing I think is somewhat irrelevant but what I do think though is the demand tends to flow through towards newer platforms. And I think we see that with the 3000, we see that with the 6000. I mean the 6000 just blew it out. And I think that some of that is people might be buying a new 6000  instead of a couple 3000, sold a couple of 2000s, and then the public sector business hit. If you look at our 2000 family, it kind of goes into a few categories. There are some that goes into the big accounts for like branch office types of things. And that was kind of mediocre, the channel business, which mostly has the midsized enterprise and small businesses, state local governments, was actually strong. And then it was the public sector use, which could be anything from ships to cars to boats to planes to whatever and that was very weak. And that was the big mover on the platform in this quarter.
