componenttext: Welcome to the NetApp Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2012 Conference Call. My name is John, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Ms. Tara Dhillon. Ms. Dhillon, you may begin.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us. With me on today's call are our CEO, Tom Georgens; our CFO, Steve Gomo; and our EVP and Global Controller, Nicholas Noviello. This call is being webcast live and will be available for replay on our websi
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us. With me on today's call are our CEO, Tom Georgens; our CFO, Steve Gomo; and our EVP and Global Controller, Nicholas Noviello. This call is being webcast live and will be available for replay on our website at netapp.com, along with the earnings release, the supplemental commentary, our financial tables and our non-GAAP to GAAP reconciliation. As a reminder during today's call we will make forward-looking statements and projections including our financial outlook for Q3, our future operating metrics, the benefits to us and our customers of new product introductions, the adequacy of our future inventory supply, our expectations regarding our future competitive position and the benefits we expect from our partnerships and strategic alliances, all of which involve risks and uncertainty Actual results may differ materially from our statements and projections. Factors that could cause actual results to differ include, among others, general macroeconomic and market conditions, particularly the continuing fiscal challenges in the U.S. and Europe, the effects of flooding in Thailand, customer demand for our products and services including our recently announced new product introductions and other equally important factors, which are detailed in our accompanying press release, which we have filed on an 8-K with the SEC, as well as our 10-K and 10-Q reports also on file with the SEC and available on our website, all of which are incorporated by reference in today's discussion. 
All numbers discussed today are GAAP unless stated otherwise. The reconciling items between non-GAAP and GAAP that we refer to a table on our press release, our supplemental commentary or our website. In a moment, Steve will provide you with some additional color on our financial results, Nick will walk you through our guidance for Q3 of FY '12. And then Tom will walk you through his perspective on the business this quarter. I'll now turn the call over to Steve for his thoughts. Steve?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tara, and good afternoon, everyone. This quarter financial performance can be characterized by contrast. In terms of business demand, we continue to see strength across most of our business with the normal puts and takes. For instance, our Euro
componenttext:
Thank you, Tara, and good afternoon, everyone. This quarter financial performance can be characterized by contrast. In terms of business demand, we continue to see strength across most of our business with the normal puts and takes. For instance, our European enterprise and our Asia PAC geographies were robust and our E-Series OEM had another solid quarter. 
Similarly, our volume channel businesses were very strong and our largest channel partners demonstrated solid growth, where we saw underperformance to our revenue forecast within our major account program. Our Q2 guidance included an analysis of the business dynamics associated with these large accounts,  their seasonality as well as relatively modest expectations for sequential revenue growth from them. Of the 46 accounts in the program, just 9 of the U.S. accounts produced the entire shortfall from the midpoint of our revenue guidance. Nevertheless, despite lower-than-expected revenue, with our non-GAAP operating margin and non-GAAP earnings per share were quite strong with non-GAAP EPS above our targeted range and at record level. 
Our total OEM revenues were strongest quarter at $230 million, growing 8% sequentially from Q1. NetApp brand revenues grew 3% sequentially, impacted primarily by softness on those 9 major accounts I just mentioned. 
Software entitlements and maintenance revenue and services revenue showed a sequential decline this quarter. In the case of SEM, the revenue decline was a function of a minor perturbation in our deferred revenue schedule. For the services revenue, the sequential decline was due to a Q2 drop in professional services revenue, which tends to be lumpy. The underlying revenue growth trends for both SEM and service maintenance contracts remain intact. Moreover, our deferred revenue balance increased by $56 million sequentially and grew 25% year-over-year. We expect that the absolute revenue level will increase for both of these revenue categories next quarter. 
Our non-GAAP product gross margins declined 0.6 percentage points from Q1 levels as the favorable effects of increased volume and configuration mix were more than offset by increased mix of E-Series OEM business, warranty cost and some pricing discount. Normalizing for mix, these product margins remain within the range of our expectation. 
Non-GAAP service gross margin declined 3.2 percentage points sequentially primarily as a result of a loss on a single transaction. We expect the services margin to bounce back next quarter. The underlying service maintenance contract gross margin remains very healthy. 
Our non-GAAP operating expenses increased less than 1% sequentially this quarter as we maintained our discipline on expense management. Employment growth moderated during the quarter and was lower than every quarter in the past year. 
The Q2 non-GAAP tax rate was also lower than forecast, finishing the quarter at 16.4% as we're now anticipating a larger mix of our FY '12 pretax earnings will come from international geographies. We expect our tax rate to return to about 17.5% next quarter and average of 17.5% for FY '12. 
Our balance sheet remains strong with approximately $4.6 billion in cash and investment, down only slightly from Q1 despite the $400 million accelerated share repurchase we executed early in the quarter. Our accounts receivable, day sales outstanding was relatively steady as it increased to 38 days from the 37 days reported in Q1. Inventory turns decrease again this quarter to 14.1x. 
There are several reasons for this including a large proactive pre-buy flash memory and a large disc drive pre-buy as the flooding in Thailand was unfolding. We believe we will have sufficient drive inventory through to the end of December but it's difficult for anyone to predict the business impact beyond that. 
Cash from operations at $370 million increased 4% from the same period last year. Free cash flow finished the quarter at $277 million. Our diluted share count decreased by 29.5 million shares sequentially to about 376 million shares primarily due to a lower average quarterly share price and to our share repurchase. 
Our average quarterly closing price was down from last quarter to $38.25 per share. The accounting per share is associated with our convertible notes and warrants had a large impact, removing about 17 million shares from the diluted share count on a sequential basis, leaving about 7 million shares to account for the convertible notes. 
As you may recall, 80% of the convertible notes are hedged. If we were to do just the share count to reflect the bond hedged then the non-GAAP EPS would have been about $0.01 higher. You can find a table on our website, which shows the impact on the diluted share count for a range of stock prices. 
In a moment, I'll turn the call over to Nick to talk to you about our guidance given his responsibility in January. As I said last quarter, it's been a goal of mine to retire by the time I'm 60 and that milestone is all too close. December 31 will be my last day at NetApp. And therefore, this is my last earnings call. I've enjoyed working with all of you over the years and I hope to have an opportunity to say goodbye over the next 6 weeks. In the meantime, my CFO responsibilities remain the same as Nick and I work together to facilitate a smooth leadership transition. We will be in great hands in the first of 2012. So at this point, I'll turn the call over to Nick

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and many thanks for your mentorship over the years. I'm sure I speak for everyone at NetApp when I say you will truly be missed. Now looking forward, our target revenue range for Q3 is at $1.52 billion to $1.61 billion, which at the mi
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and many thanks for your mentorship over the years. I'm sure I speak for everyone at NetApp when I say you will truly be missed. 
Now looking forward, our target revenue range for Q3 is at $1.52 billion to $1.61 billion, which at the midpoint implies approximately 4% sequential growth and 21% year-over-year growth. Consolidated non-GAAP gross margins are expected to finish around 60%. We expect that non-GAAP operating margins will finish around 17%. As Steve mentioned earlier, we expect our blended consolidated non-GAAP effective tax rate to be approximately 17.5% based upon a shift in distribution of our earnings to our international geographies, bringing our non-GAAP earnings per share estimate to approximately $0.56 to $0.60 per share. 
Diluted share count is forecast to increase to about 380 million shares in Q3 based on our average stock price of $41.84 for the first 10 days of the quarter. This will include about 9 million shares from the convertible notes and 0.5 million shares from the warrant. Recall that the favorable impact of the note hedges is not included as an offset. If we were to adjust the share count for the convertible note hedged, that would add about $0.01 to the EPS guidance. 
To summarize, our business model continued to show its underlying resiliency in the second quarter as we exceeded our operating margin and EPS target despite some revenue softness. In fact for the first half, we generated 23% year-over-year revenue growth at a non-GAAP operating margin of 18.5%. However, the original financial targets we laid out at our Analyst Day did not foresee the 2 substantial macroeconomic factors we find ourselves managing through today. Those being the increasing economic turmoil in Europe and flooding in Thailand. These conditions make forecasting both revenue and cost of sales going forward far less predictable. Therefore, we cannot confidently forecast a specific range for Q4 revenue and earnings per share at this time. We will provide you with an update on our Q3 earnings call. 
At this point, I'll turn the call over to Tom for his thoughts. Tom?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nick, and good afternoon, everyone. As a Steve indicated, the sequential decline in our major account program in a quarter where we expected seasonal growth was the biggest deviation from our forecast. While we were not anticipating sequential gro
componenttext:
Thanks, Nick, and good afternoon, everyone. As a Steve indicated, the sequential decline in our major account program in a quarter where we expected seasonal growth was the biggest deviation from our forecast. While we were not anticipating sequential growth comparable to last year, we needed better performance from this group to meet our objectives. Fortunately, most of the unexpected shortfall was confined to a small number of accounts, where the customer-specific dynamics can be understood. Unlike last quarter, the companies were not concentrated in any specific industry. Beyond this concentrated shortfall, the rest of the businesses were generally positive. 
The strength in the other areas of our business is evident when looking at it from a geographical perspective. Our U.S. Commercial business grew 24% year-over-year. Our Asia-Pacific business grew 55% year-over-year and our EMEA business grew 12% year-over-year in a challenging environment. 
Our E-Series OEM business remains well ahead of plans with 11% sequential growth. We even saw some rebound in spending from the financial services sector. We also saw some budget flush in the U.S. Public Sector, which were up only 9% year-over-year, it was over a margin compare and it grew 56% sequentially. 
Outside of those 9 major accounts, our Enterprise business was generally strong. Our number of transactions over $1 billion was the second highest ever, increasing 17% sequentially and over 30% year-over-year, while the total net new customer account acquisition is at a 2.5-year high. The volume segments of the business around midsized enterprise at state, local and higher education were very robust and the highest growth areas of the portfolio. 
Our emphasis on pathway diversification continues to pay off as we saw record sales from our indirect channels, representing the highest ever percentage of our revenue. Our largest distribution partners Arrow and AppNet grew 31% of total revenue and grew 18% year-over-year. CBW, our largest reseller in fiscal year '12, who over 75% year-over-year. 
Our alliance program continues to generate leverage as we broaden our portfolio of tightly integrated service offerings in partnership with other, vendors. We are in the process of conducting our Global Insight Events where we train thousands of technical resources both internally and from our resellers and partners. At the event, we further enhanced our solution offerings by introducing 4 new verified architectures: Microsoft Private Cloud, Oracle Database, Media Content Management and FlexPod Data Center Solutions. 
FlexPod is our modular data center solution developed in conjunction with Cisco to provide partners and customers with an integrated standardized and scalable and for structure to support a variety of workloads. Together, we have a validated designs for VMware, SharePoint, SAP, Citrix and Red Hat Linux. 
FlexPod had another strong quarter and our relationship with Cisco continues to deepen as a result. We now have over 400 FlexPod customers and a robust pipeline for future FlexPod business. On the product side, the new 3000 and 6000 platforms both have solid quarters. Units shipped of the 3000 were up 34% year-over-year. And in fact 6000 units more than doubled over last year's Q2 levels. The 2000 was down year-over-year and down slightly on a sequential basis. 
We saw decreased demand in double channel in our Large Enterprises as well as the shift in business to the newer 3000 family. However, last week, we introduced newly designed 2000 class models for this segment with our smart decisions are built on NetApp campaign. With refresh technology, attractive price points and our latest Data ONTAP 8.1 operating system, it represents a compelling solution for each of its target segments. 
Our product launch had a particular focus on the midsize enterprise and our state, local and higher education channels where our momentum is strong and the partners are eager to introduce the new offerings to their customers. In addition to being the standard operating system on our 2000 series, Data ONTAP 8.1 is now available on our 3000 and 6000 platforms. Our 8.1 operating system is the first product in the market to marry the industry's richest portfolio of data management and storage efficiency technologies with clustering to enable unmatched scalability and nonstop operations. 
Previous architectures, including both traditional approaches and newer niche implementations, have forced customers to make trade-offs amongst these features. NetApp is the only vendor to have a functionality and configurability to produce optimized solutions for the widest range of applications including virtualization, technical computing, competent repositories and traditional business applications all from a single architecture. 
Evidence on the scalability was demonstrated where recently published compelling results from an independent spec FAS benchmark test in which a 24-node cluster of NetApp FAS6000 with the 8.1 produced 1.5 million ops per second. That's over 35% faster than the previous record and we did it with 50% fewer discs and 80% fewer controller nodes, demonstrating a real-world configuration with far better results in far lower cost. 
Our total E-Series product family continues to make a big impact as well. Our 14% sequential growth was driven by a specially strong demand from Teradata and Dell, but our other 2 major OEMs on IBM and Oracle were up sequentially as well. We have been sufficiently clear about our commitment to this business. Initially in words and now, in behavior, that each of our major OEM partners have confirmed the expectation of an ongoing relationship and a couple of our introduced new offerings based on the E-Series technology. 
The E-Series products are also key to our Big Data strategy in the areas of analytics and big bandwidth. For analytics, E-Series has now been designed into 3 integrated analytic appliances. We also have integrated into our initial Hadoop solutions and partner engagements. 
For Big Bandwidth, we're continually broadening the solution offerings to our field enabling some high-profile Full-Motion Video and High Performance Computing wins. All in all, our business operated largely within the balance of our expectation this quarter and we're not for an exception of an expected large slowdown in a handful of our biggest accounts, we were at least at the midpoint of our targeted revenue range. 
And we continue this ability in Europe, the persistent economic uncertainty in the U.S. and the associated uncertainty around federal spending, all things considered, the rest of the business was essentially in line or slightly better than we anticipated 90 days ago. Nonetheless, the response to the aggregated revenue performance, the organization once again demonstrated its ability to manage through the business model, enabling us to increase our operating margins over the last quarter and produce record earnings per share. 
Looking ahead, the impact of the Thailand flooding can potentially be the biggest swing factor on both our top and bottom line in the second half. The large buyer drives we did as this was all unfolding should sustain us to a good part of Q3 but probably not all of it. Although enterprise class drives are considered to be the least impacted, we still anticipate some amount of supply and pricing complexity. We have all heard the predictions of the industry analyst and the drive vendors themselves. Some of the information is conflicting and most of it is changing daily in regards to scope and ultimate impact. 
I expect NetApp will fare better than most in this process. But it's far too early to state the exact extent this will impact our business either directly or through our OEM partners. On the other hand, our FAS business will begin to get uplift from the just reset, refreshed 2000 series and our partners and technical teams are coming off in an invigorating symposium where they will brief on Data ONTAP 8.1 and competing using NetApp products. 
I believe NetApp continues to have the best product portfolio and the best partnerships in the industry, both of which will pay off in the long run. Before I open up the call to Q&A, I'd like to again thank Steve for more than 9 years of tremendous contributions to NetApp. 
I'd also like to congratulate the entire NetApp team for being ranked #3 on the world's best multinational list by the Great Place Work Institute. The culture at NetApp is one of the key to success and this recognition is a strong validation of our commitment to creating a model company. It is this commitment that will drive us to continue to gain market share in both good and challenging times. 
At this point, I'll open up the call for Q&A. As always, I'll ask that you be respectable of your peers on the call and limit yourself to one question so we can try to address everyone in our allotted time today. Thank you. Operator?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Katy Huberty for Morgan Stanley.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: You obviously did a great job in the channel as well as with signing up new accounts this quarter. But just a question on pricing because Dell last night talked about more price competition in the midrange. I wonder if there were some variability in prici
componenttext: You obviously did a great job in the channel as well as with signing up new accounts this quarter. But just a question on pricing because Dell last night talked about more price competition in the midrange. I wonder if there were some variability in pricing in order for you to win those deals in the midrange this quarter?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Katy, I say in the channel probably not so much. Clearly, that's a competitive business and certainly our largest competitor there is being aggressive in the channel. And certainly is doing a number of incentives to gain share again or gain mine share. Bu
componenttext: Katy, I say in the channel probably not so much. Clearly, that's a competitive business and certainly our largest competitor there is being aggressive in the channel. And certainly is doing a number of incentives to gain share again or gain mine share. But I would say frankly the pricing dynamics are a lot more complicated with large accounts because they see obviously lesser demand and the opportunity to take advantage of that. So I say the pricing environment is probably no different, which isn't to say that it's calm. It's just to say that it's no different. But the pricing is relevant I'd say, it's probably a little bit more on the major account side.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Moskowitz from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Moskowitz from JPMorgan.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you a question, Tom, regarding the overall, your comments on expected, now expect the weakness of your largest accounts. Was this due to macro events, company-specific events, NetApp's inability to deliver? Is there a competitive dynamic?
componenttext: I wanted to ask you a question, Tom, regarding the overall, your comments on expected, now expect the weakness of your largest accounts. Was this due to macro events, company-specific events, NetApp's inability to deliver? Is there a competitive dynamic? I guess if you can just qualify or provide us some context that would be greatly appreciated.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there 2 things in play here. One of them is the performance of the accounts and the other one is what was our expectation of the performance. I think there's certainly some accounts that certainly have well-known headlines that we knew going
componenttext: Yes, I think there 2 things in play here. One of them is the performance of the accounts and the other one is what was our expectation of the performance. I think there's certainly some accounts that certainly have well-known headlines that we knew going into the quarter we're going to have some issues associated with them. Certainly, I was concerned about the DoD and federal spending and obviously, some individual accounts that we're probably are well aware of. That we knew are going to be problematic and we factored that into the forecast. I think that the other ones we actually probably expected more of our normal Q1 to Q2 seasonality as we think about them and that's really not what happened. And I'd also add that these were not necessarily problem accounts. These are accounts may have on the ascendancy that shows the slowdown. So we want to indicate that we've actually had 9 more problem accounts on our major account portfolio. I think some of those are clearly in the ascendancy with NetApp, which is that we are expecting more from them this particular quarter. I think from competitive pressures I think certainly pricing clearly in a market where demand is limited, there's a lot of capacity chasing deals. Our customers are using that to their advantage. But for a pure competitor perspective, in those 9 accounts, there's probably only one that I would say has a meaningful competitive component to it. But I think all the other ones are either macro related or company-specific.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Erin from Stifel Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Erin from Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I want to ask on first of all, a clarification. I heard you say 11% sequential growth on E-Series and I also heard you say 14% sequential, so clarifying that. And then if I look at that and I look at your organic revenue growth at roughly 6% by my math, I
componenttext: I want to ask on first of all, a clarification. I heard you say 11% sequential growth on E-Series and I also heard you say 14% sequential, so clarifying that. And then if I look at that and I look at your organic revenue growth at roughly 6% by my math, I know you talked about gaining market share in down and up markets. How do we think about your organic growth profile? Or how are you thinking about the organic growth profile here over the next couple of quarters in that mindset of what is the market going to grow here looking out in 2012?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think first of all on the E-Series we probably think there are 2 different data points. One was E-Series OEM business and then the other one was the E-Series  overall. So the E-Series  OEM business had a more natural compare than the overall since
componenttext: Yes, I think first of all on the E-Series we probably think there are 2 different data points. One was E-Series OEM business and then the other one was the E-Series  overall. So the E-Series  OEM business had a more natural compare than the overall since we just really started with the branded business that's why that number is a little bit higher. So and of course, those are our revenue number. I believe on the last call, I talked about the large $14 million deal that would not come to revenue this quarter. And that's clearly still true if you're wondering where the $14 million went. I think on the broader question, the real question here as we think about the market and we think about the macro, the NetApp's focus is almost exclusively on market share because that's really the true measure of our penetration. And the key component in market share, the only thing that actually gets counted in the market share as reported by the industry analysts is actually product revenue growth. So as you think about companies in the space with product transitions and acquisitions, I think we're dealing with a different macro environment this year than we were last year. I think probably it might be the best way to think about that is actually taking about sequential growth. So if I look at our sequential growth from last quarter, there's about 5.2% on the product side. So if I compare that to say, EMC's product growth in storage, the most recent quarter, I think that number is about 1.2%. So you could say it's a NetApp Q1 to Q2. For them, it's a Q2 to Q3. But if you go back another quarter with EMC and look at the Q1 to Q2 transition to them that's only about 2%. So from a market share perspective, which is really a measure of product growth, NetApp actually had more sequential growth in the last 3 months and the EMC's last in on a percentage basis. So to the extent that it's #1 or #2 market share players in this market, I had to think that our market share gains are greater than this.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jayson Noland from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jayson Noland from Robert W. Baird.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: A question for you or Nick, just trying to get a sense for what's in the guidance, your expectations for the 2240. Are you assuming constraints in the HDD world? And on the major account is there any push up there into this upcoming quarter?
componenttext: A question for you or Nick, just trying to get a sense for what's in the guidance, your expectations for the 2240. Are you assuming constraints in the HDD world? And on the major account is there any push up there into this upcoming quarter?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Nick. Just to give you perspective on the new products, certainly there's a pickup of new products that resulted in the guidance. As we mentioned on the drive the side of the fence, we talked about availability through the end of the calenda
componenttext: Sure, this is Nick. Just to give you perspective on the new products, certainly there's a pickup of new products that resulted in the guidance. As we mentioned on the drive the side of the fence, we talked about availability through the end of the calendar year. Certainly it gets a little bit more complicated once you get into the new year. So what we've built in on the guidance is many of the positives that talk about for this quarter continuing the new products coming in but those overall constraints on drives from Thailand and macro being there that we have to consider when we build the guidance.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And one other thing I say on the 2240 is we've seen a decline in low-end units over the past actually 9 months or so. And I would say, it will be fairly easy for us to say we should expect to get all those units back in all the incremental. But the other
componenttext: And one other thing I say on the 2240 is we've seen a decline in low-end units over the past actually 9 months or so. And I would say, it will be fairly easy for us to say we should expect to get all those units back in all the incremental. But the other thing to notice of our business is that the segments of the market that are most dependent upon products of that class, which is our volume channel business have the strongest part of our business so. Clearly they moved some of the demands to the new 3000. So I would expect some of that demand to actually come back from the 3000 into the 2000. So I wouldn't, it would be really easy for me to say that it will be incremental. But I think that there will be some reversed cannibalization of the 3000 just like what we saw when the 3000 came out. As far as the enterprise and Department of Defense or I'll just say U.S. Public Sector, those are big consumers of this class of products as well. And there is some attributes of this product in terms of size and compatibility with prior products, which actually will enable the product transition in our favor here that was held up in the previous generation. So I do expect not only this will impact our channel business but I do expect this to impact our enterprise and our U.S. Public Sector business as well.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bill Shope from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bill Shope from Goldman Sachs.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm a little confused on the weakness in the 9 accounts. Can you help us understand, I understand that you can't lump in the weakness into one specific reason for all of them, but how are you addressing the weakness? Is there some execution issues that yo
componenttext: I'm a little confused on the weakness in the 9 accounts. Can you help us understand, I understand that you can't lump in the weakness into one specific reason for all of them, but how are you addressing the weakness? Is there some execution issues that you're looking at? And my memory may be foggy but this sounds somewhat similar to the shortfall you guys had in mid-2007 where you had some issues with large accounts. And I know you were able to reconcile that with basically a different approach to a broader customer base. How should we compare it to that prior hick up understanding that there was a big recession here later and sort of how should we think about how you're addressing this weakness and preventing it from spreading frankly?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if you think about it from last quarter clearly, the federal side was the concern for us. We're lapping up the quarter in the face of that crisis and I don't really know whether that impacted that us or not. But also last call, we talked abou
componenttext: Yes, I think if you think about it from last quarter clearly, the federal side was the concern for us. We're lapping up the quarter in the face of that crisis and I don't really know whether that impacted that us or not. But also last call, we talked about the U.S. Public Sector and we talked about financial services. So you can actually argue that's is actually even more concentrated than it was last quarter so instead of spreading it might actually be contracting. But as far as the accounts are we need to look at every single one of them, more than clearly it's really visually competitive or it's largely competitive and I think we need to take that on clearly. I think that's than anybody. But I think most of the other ones I think our most of those accounts that are actually doing quite well from a NetApp perspective. And they took a pause. And some of them obviously, we did some insight to see when we expect them to come back. Some of them some of them will pause a little bit longer based on their own company dynamics. So I think that the advantage of it being a definable set of named accounts is that we can build and actually play around each every single one of them. As opposed to if we saw a broad weakness in the channel, that would be 1000 account problems. So I think there are things that we're going to jump onto. I'd say that most of those accounts are still relatively favorable and we're not losing any share in them. We may or may not, depending on each individual situation as you see a rebound next quarter and that's factored into our guidance.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the comparison to 2007, is that relevant or?
componenttext: And the comparison to 2007, is that relevant or?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think 2007 was had a much, much greater concentration in financial services. In fact I would argue that last quarter dynamic was more than 2007 than this one. I'd also want to be clear. In fact financial services came back in a big way. Certainly, they
componenttext: I think 2007 was had a much, much greater concentration in financial services. In fact I would argue that last quarter dynamic was more than 2007 than this one. I'd also want to be clear. In fact financial services came back in a big way. Certainly, they didn't have a 50-something percent sequential increase like our Federal business did. So but some of them did come back and some of them came back in a meaningful way. And we anticipated some of that in our guidance as well. So it's not universal. I think last quarter, we had 6 major accounts in financial services and they were all down, a bit more balanced this time.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Marshall from ISI Group.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Marshall from ISI Group.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess a little bit of a confusion with respect to the your 9 large customers and the top 46. I mean if that was really the shortfall and call $50 million of call, roughly $5 million per account, are we talking mostly on the 6000 series here? Because tha
componenttext: I guess a little bit of a confusion with respect to the your 9 large customers and the top 46. I mean if that was really the shortfall and call $50 million of call, roughly $5 million per account, are we talking mostly on the 6000 series here? Because that business was up 100% year-over-year so I'm just trying to tie those 2 together, what these guys are actually buying and what went down?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't necessarily tie it to the 6000. And simply put, there's 2 things to factor in. One of them is the amount of money that they were down and the other one is the amount of seasonality uplift that we were expecting from Q1. So I think there's both
componenttext: I wouldn't necessarily tie it to the 6000. And simply put, there's 2 things to factor in. One of them is the amount of money that they were down and the other one is the amount of seasonality uplift that we were expecting from Q1. So I think there's both of those that come into play. But suffice to say that if they came in as expected, we would've sold even more 3000 than 6000s and there probably some 2000s as well. So I think that the strength of those business I think we're heartened by the fact that the significant movements in certainly the high-end, included some indication about the customers and the types of applications that were deployed in but the 3000 was quite strong. I would allow that reversed cannibalization of the 3000 going into the next quarter going back to the 2000. But the 6000 remains robust and it could've been even more so, certainly had some of these accounts come true.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Glenn Hanus from Needham & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Glenn Hanus from Needham & Company.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: About, let's talk about the intermediate term business model. You were pretty responsive in controlling operating expenses. You mentioned 17% operating margin this quarter. Is there sort of an intermediate target that we should be thinking about and how w
componenttext: About, let's talk about the intermediate term business model. You were pretty responsive in controlling operating expenses. You mentioned 17% operating margin this quarter. Is there sort of an intermediate target that we should be thinking about and how will you sort of manage to that target?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Nicholas, just to help you understand on the operating expense perspective, we've taken some measures there. What you see in the 17% is the impact from Thailand though, right? So that is something that we have to build into our planning and really
componenttext: This is Nicholas, just to help you understand on the operating expense perspective, we've taken some measures there. What you see in the 17% is the impact from Thailand though, right? So that is something that we have to build into our planning and really driving that change from what you might see on the business model side and on that 18%-plus model that we've been, so far. And you'll see it actually of the growth margins that I gave you on the guidance on earlier.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, the one thing I just from a point of view of managing the business I think from this particular quarter, I think once again we proved that we wanted to put some control on expense that we can snap back, to use the 2007 analogy I think we obviously sl
componenttext: Yes, the one thing I just from a point of view of managing the business I think from this particular quarter, I think once again we proved that we wanted to put some control on expense that we can snap back, to use the 2007 analogy I think we obviously slowed down. I said we would be back in the model in the year. We were back in the quarter. The one thing that is a little bit different this time is on the matter of Thailand, clearly, this concern about availability but there's also concern about pricing drag. And from the point of view of managing to the P&L and managing to the business model, I think under normal as consensus really we would modulate circumstances to protect the business model. But if we think were going to get hit as a result of this transaction and certainly would modeling some of that in that's going to be temporary in nature. I don't want whip saw the operation and modulate operating expense based on pricing of disc drives. But frankly to the extent that the gross margin is impacted by the drive situation that's going to flow through the bottom line on a temporary basis and the operating expenses is going to be more modulated by the overall size of the opportunity that we see.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011

componenttext: Okay. Sorry, Nick So just to be clear, so what I'm really trying to slice is that product margin number in different ways is pricing in there is one of the variables? And then I promise I'll see the floor.

componenttext: Okay. So what's in there is certainly, Thailand is in there. And we're building that in. In addition to that is a customer mix and OEM mix. Those are the big drivers that are going to be built into that and are built into the product margin guidance for the third quarter.

componenttext: From the point of view of material pricing to us particularly disk drives that's factored in, that's  pricing to end users. Our expectation is that not going to be materially different than what we saw this quarter.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kaushik Roy from Merriman Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kaushik Roy from Merriman Capital.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tom, can you comment on the use of flash? We know you used flash cash as so SSDs. But can you comment on your offering or may be PPIE FFTs on the servers?
componenttext: Tom, can you comment on the use of flash? We know you used flash cash as so SSDs. But can you comment on your offering or may be PPIE FFTs on the servers?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: So we kind of dropped the flash out of the commentary because flash is not bundled into more and more and more of our systems. It is becoming an integral part of these types of arrays. And the ability of flash and ATA drives as we move higher cost from en
componenttext: So we kind of dropped the flash out of the commentary because flash is not bundled into more and more and more of our systems. It is becoming an integral part of these types of arrays. And the ability of flash and ATA drives as we move higher cost from enterprise drives, it clearly drive the cost point at very, very competitive and is driven up adoption. So that is bundled in and not exactly tied to customer preference. It's hard to talk about flash adoption but I would venture to guess certainly on the 6000 and the majority of the 3000 is the part of the solution.  So the way we go from here, I think you'll continue to see innovation on the flash side from NetApp, both inside and outside the array. I don't want to preannounce any products. So i don't think that I think the planning horizon in the model that you guys are trying to put up for Q3, I think you should expect that flash drives are going to be substantial the way it is. As far as PCI flash products, yes, you need to be clear on what the opportunity is there. I think for us, things that are going to represent permanent storage, we want to bring into our data management methodology. So that clearly is our interest. As far as flash-based PCI board as a revenue opportunity on a stand-alone basis, that's not nearly as interesting to us. But if it's a vehicle to sell software and broaden our footprint, clearly that's the boat that we'll be pushing.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Freed from Wunderlich Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Freed from Wunderlich Securities.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: A real quick question on ONTAP 8.1. First, is it currently shipping as a GA product? Or is it still in a release candidate on the  FAS6000 and 3000 products family? And related to that, can you talk any about what you're seeing from a win rate perspective
componenttext: A real quick question on ONTAP 8.1. First, is it currently shipping as a GA product? Or is it still in a release candidate on the  FAS6000 and 3000 products family? And related to that, can you talk any about what you're seeing from a win rate perspective? Are you seeing any visible signs of improvement particularly in scale-out aspects?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, from a 2000, it's in every unit out of the factory so it's basically the standard operating system that we ship, so the 3000 and 6000 still obviously an option. They're shipping a prior version on ONTAP 8.1 as a default. And I think they can actuall
componenttext: Well, from a 2000, it's in every unit out of the factory so it's basically the standard operating system that we ship, so the 3000 and 6000 still obviously an option. They're shipping a prior version on ONTAP 8.1 as a default. And I think they can actually ship, to some of the models also. So in terms of win rates particularly around scale ONTAP scale, it isn't just about 8.1, we're certainly competing with cluster node in that technology with existing functionality of 8.x. And I think what 8.1 brings to us is not only the performance that's you saw the new operating system on the platforms clearly is compelling but. What it also does is it reduces the trade off necessary of trade off clustering versus the premium software features. So many of the premium software features of our standard version of ONTAP are now fully clusterable. And from that perspective, obviously the product has much broader appeal not just scale out mass but really around traditional applications. They really have very, very, rich data management, which is not typical of products in traditional business applications. And then next clustering virtually gives tremendous possibility and build scale of performance of capacity and also clustering is a key enabling technology of a true nonstop operation. So from our perspective, the scale out ONTAP is just one data point. But the real focus of our 8.x journey is effectively to bring clustering and premium software features into the traditional business applications area, wherein have been relatively modest from an innovation perspective in all the period of time.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Richard Gardner from Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Richard Gardner from Citigroup.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tom, I'm  sorry to beat a dead horse but I did want to go back to the issues in the 9 accounts. On the one hand, it sounds like it's either macro or company-specific driven by you also suggested that some of these accounts are on the ascendancy with NetAp
componenttext: Tom, I'm  sorry to beat a dead horse but I did want to go back to the issues in the 9 accounts. On the one hand, it sounds like it's either macro or company-specific driven by you also suggested that some of these accounts are on the ascendancy with NetApp and have decided to put plans on hold. And it sounds like there might be, maybe a situation where you're displacing a competitor and those customers have decided to slow down the adoption of NetApp technology. So I guess what I'm really asking is how much of this really is company specific and macro, and how much of it is due to competitive dynamics in these accounts?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I also want to be clear. I'll go to my direct answer and the real dynamic here is not the overall fundamental health of those accounts. As the performance of those accounts this quarter against our expectations the performance this quarter that we ha
componenttext: Yes, I also want to be clear. I'll go to my direct answer and the real dynamic here is not the overall fundamental health of those accounts. As the performance of those accounts this quarter against our expectations the performance this quarter that we had 90 days ago. So there're clearly some accounts that might be problematic growth accounts for company-specific reasons. And we knew that going in. And those weren't factored in. And those might be accounts that might be tough for us to drive growth in overtime whether we gain share from them or not. On the other hand, these are accounts where we've had higher expectations by what they did, which is to say that they're broken on they're damaged and that they're losing ground. So and some of these accounts made a lot of progress. And they all did spend money, it's just a question of not as much. So I think from that perspective, I realize that ultimately, not needing to a satisfactory answer you keep coming back to it. But I say that overall the point is it that the major accounts in general are being a proxy for the broader environment as certainly price pressure both from a pricing perspective and from a demand perspective. And I think that those accounts being large as they stop and go, have a much bigger impact on our business. So those 9 accounts had a disproportionate amount of our business relative to our expectation, which isn't to say that we're in trouble that any of them like I said, I think the competitive pressures are really only relevant in one. And they aren't necessarily the 9 worst accounts because clearly, we have accounts that we know are going to be problematic and certainly sectors are going to be problem but those were already factored into our forecast. So I just want to be clear it's not like we only have 9 accounts that we're not happy with. I think these accounts will be very strong for us going forward and there will be other accounts that are not on this list that we know are going to be problematic and that was factored into our guidance. And is continued to be factored into our guidance going forward.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Scott Craig from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Scott Craig from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a clarification on the guidance. I think I heard you say that you are assuming a pickup in the major accounts, maybe just clarify that. And then secondly, if that pick up doesn't happen, Nick, what are you guys compared to do on the OpEx line and wha
componenttext: Just a clarification on the guidance. I think I heard you say that you are assuming a pickup in the major accounts, maybe just clarify that. And then secondly, if that pick up doesn't happen, Nick, what are you guys compared to do on the OpEx line and what can you do to sort of mitigate some of the potential or revenue shortfall if we see continued slow down?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Nick. Just in terms of your comment on pickup in major accounts. First of all, again, we go through an account planning and build a view of where our major accounts are going to go this coming quarter. Similar to what Tom has said, there wasn't a
componenttext: This is Nick. Just in terms of your comment on pickup in major accounts. First of all, again, we go through an account planning and build a view of where our major accounts are going to go this coming quarter. Similar to what Tom has said, there wasn't a lot of growth built into last quarter. So we're not expecting a lot this coming quarter. We do a bottoms up, that's built in and that's how we've kind of come up with the guidance on those. On the OpEx side of the sense and really back to the question of operating margins, the operating margin shortfall is really reflected in the gross margin shortfall. And the gross margin shortfall is driven by the cost pressure that we believe is going to come and we're seeing a little bit of in terms of drive situation that is out there. So that's built into product gross margins, that flows through to the overall operating margin line. And I made reference before to the OpEx as a percentage of revenue is basically flat to the expense structure we've managed pretty well.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think going forward, it's kind of if we were trying to about operating expenses and it will be all the usual things, it will programs, it will be the hiring and things of that nature. If you look at this quarter similar to last quarter, we came in over
componenttext: I think going forward, it's kind of if we were trying to about operating expenses and it will be all the usual things, it will programs, it will be the hiring and things of that nature. If you look at this quarter similar to last quarter, we came in over the top of EPS side. And clearly, the revenue didn't come from our forecast in the K. So we're quite cognizant of that. So the issue that we're trying to solve here obviously is work on to drive growth as opposed to do with operating expense. On the other hand with some uncertainty ahead but macroeconomic we and also the trial of flooding, we need to be careful about where the top line is going and therefore, we are prudent with up to this particular quarter. So we're still hiring 300-something people. It's not like we're sitting out and die but that's the balance that we need to have going forward is how do we model the spending in proportion to the business. But I also want to be clear as I said earlier the impact of the Thailand flood, we expect to be temporary. And I'm not going to modulate operating expense on it  because: a, it's going to be hard to predict and I hate to just kind of change the organization around a set of data points that are changing everyday.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Maynard Um from UBS.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you more broadly addressed this issue. I was hoping you could be a bit more direct. Are  any changes within your customer base around with thinking about their storage architectures or technologies? I'm curious just given kind of EMC's commentary
componenttext: I think you more broadly addressed this issue. I was hoping you could be a bit more direct. Are  any changes within your customer base around with thinking about their storage architectures or technologies? I'm curious just given kind of EMC's commentary that its product has been displacing what they say, vendor that didn't scale for general-purpose need. Can you just help kind of clear the air there what you're seeing in the market from that standpoint?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think specifically on the case, I mean certainly we see certainly in places around the Solera, we certainly see them, our accounts. I think when we think about, clearly they were targeting us before EMC brought them and certainly that has not let
componenttext: Well, I think specifically on the case, I mean certainly we see certainly in places around the Solera, we certainly see them, our accounts. I think when we think about, clearly they were targeting us before EMC brought them and certainly that has not let up. It's approximately causing these accounts like I said, the accounts that are on the ascendancy have suddenly stopped buying or paused for a period of time. That was an intercept of the business by a competitive activity. Certainly if that was a threat we're contracting the forecast 90 days ago things like that don't happen that quickly. As far as, itself, if you look at the value points that it has around NAS performance, data value point has really about manageability of large content tools. From a strict performance perspective, it's subjectively measured clearly the E-Series the high performance computing is clearly much higher performance. Certainly the benchmark that we just did around that spec and, scalability are dramatically. Clearly, from a performance perspective NetApp is more than able to hold its own. In fact, it has a compelling leadership position there. On a general question of manageability, that's kind of a tough thing to objectively benchmark. But if you look at where we're strongest at now with 8.1, the marriage of other premium features which don't exist in that the product. And therefore, it makes it difficult to sell into traditional business applications. And also kind of the merger where we're heading, with the, acquisition and object-oriented stuff, effectively going to be bringing the functionality of both, and if you will. So I feel good about our roadmap. I think clearly from a performance perspective, NetApp is really taking the high ground. And I think from the perspective, obviously that's a little bit harder to objectively measure but I think you'll see much better functionality from NetApp and continued competitive from that front. So I think where I see, is from the premium side of the business around performance and key scientific applications more than comfortable with our stance there. In terms of large content repository pools kind of lower value data, that's primarily manageability and you'll certainly hear more from NetApp hopefully at 8.1 and in the future releases. So from us, do we see them? Yes. Will there be a certain pause over the dynamics of the major accounts? Certainly we see them but they were not the primary cause of what we saw some 90 days ago.

componenttext: One quick clarification for Nick and one question for Tom. Nick, on the gross margin, obviously the guide down here implies closer to 300 to 350 basis point, product margin declined. Should we think about the vast majority of that assumption being tied to higher drive cost and temporary in nature?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Two points there to keep in mind and yes, pretty close in terms of that sequential decline and product gross margin. The 2 points, you're going to have a product and customer mix including the OEM and heavier OEM that happens in the calendar third quarter
componenttext: Two points there to keep in mind and yes, pretty close in terms of that sequential decline and product gross margin. The 2 points, you're going to have a product and customer mix including the OEM and heavier OEM that happens in the calendar third quarter of every year. That's impacting part of it and then the drives are impacting the other part of it. That makes up the basic 3-point change in decline in the product gross margin.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: And Tom, my question for you. Is less about the 9 major accounts and more about the direct sales as a whole and on the absolute basis down 2 consecutive second quarters, your lowest absolute level since October of 2009. You obviously have a new software r
componenttext: And Tom, my question for you. Is less about the 9 major accounts and more about the direct sales as a whole and on the absolute basis down 2 consecutive second quarters, your lowest absolute level since October of 2009. You obviously have a new software release, 8.1, the low-end refresh. Do you think we're bottoming here on the direct side? Obviously the commentary that there's going to be a heavier OEM E-Series  mix, it suggests maybe this isn't the bottom. What's your general sense? Is there a pipeline of new customers that could drive a rebound going forward? Help us understand the direct sales opportunities that you see now. Are we close to a bottom? Are we seeing the bottom? And then what gives you confidence that you can grow that business going forward?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: The one thing that I would -- I guess the one question I would put is don't assume that the fulfillment model for the customers are static. So the fact that some of our big accounts may choose to go through a channel partner or go through an integrator or
componenttext: The one thing that I would -- I guess the one question I would put is don't assume that the fulfillment model for the customers are static. So the fact that some of our big accounts may choose to go through a channel partner or go through an integrator or the systems integrators now moving more hardware through their business. So the same involvement of our sales reps might actually have a different fulfillment model. And I think that's in play here too. The flipside to that argument and I would also argue is don't assume that our channel business has do a touch from our direct sales organization. In some cases I wish it was more independent. But our direct sales organizations involved in a lot of accounts. So I think our direct selling motion is clearly creating demand. And the question is will they fulfill it directly through NetApp or do they prefer to go to a third party. In a lot of cases that's a customer choice. So we don't actually measure demand creation by channel. So I wouldn't read into that direct salesforce number is necessarily indicative of the lower direct salesforce productivity.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's fair enough. Will discount the overall direct salesforce business but it's hard to discount the branded business that's slowing down overall. So I guess the keep that do you feel that 8.1 help drive the acceleration branded overall?
componenttext: Okay. That's fair enough. Will discount the overall direct salesforce business but it's hard to discount the branded business that's slowing down overall. So I guess the keep that do you feel that 8.1 help drive the acceleration branded overall?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think clearly 8.1, the entire 8.x family, there's really revolutionary when it comes to storage for data center environment, the ability to bring  true clustering and this premium features set. I think will help. obviously the 2000 will help as well. Cl
componenttext: I think clearly 8.1, the entire 8.x family, there's really revolutionary when it comes to storage for data center environment, the ability to bring  true clustering and this premium features set. I think will help. obviously the 2000 will help as well. Clearly, it's not uncommon for us to see pickup in demand. Certainly, the last product releases are remarkably successful in terms of conversion of customer demand. So I expect the 2000 to pick up as well. So from an overall branded business like I said, I think the other thing that you need to put in context is just what you believe about the macro environment. So I think the year-over-year growth numbers are all interesting but I think we're dealing with a different macro environment obviously, NetApp has got other elements of the portfolio now that we can rely upon for growth. But I think if you go back to a sequential number, I think the NetApp sequential product performance is actually pretty darn good this quarter than the 9 accounts on the major accounts in general notwithstanding. I think 5% sequential growth and even despite everything is going on 4% sequential growth from here if we sustain that for the next couple of years, that I would stay if we can sustain that would've a period of think that would be pretty good for us and we're in a share gaining position.

componenttext: Could you just comment on why you see a similar slowdown on the fed sector in the month of October that Dell called out last night? And then looking in the next 12 months aside from the obvious looming budget cuts, do you anticipate any headwinds or new headwinds from competitive perspective now that, is qualified, VNX is now on more GSA list?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the federal side, I mean clearly nothing, that's been very successful for us. We're in #1 market share position. Obviously, a lot of speculation in that particular business. I think all things considered over an extended period of time, a lot of other
componenttext: On the federal side, I mean clearly nothing, that's been very successful for us. We're in #1 market share position. Obviously, a lot of speculation in that particular business. I think all things considered over an extended period of time, a lot of other companies that talk about with weakness in that area while NetApp continue its momentum. So that's strong sequential growth in that business last quarter. We had growth year-over-year. So with all the headlines I think we have to be pretty pleased with the overall performance. Did I say that October have slowed down? I do think, first of all, I wouldn't over play our granularity in that regard. One thing that happens in October is we see a lot of systems integrated business that they actually win before the fiscal year end and takes a little while to go through to us. But I would say that we saw anything in October that made us any more or less pessimistic than what we saw September when the deals are actually closing.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Steve. I would just add as far as the past quarter is concerned. Remember that in the Fed business also, we have contracts that in existence today. We own the contract and what we are seeing I think a little bit in the slowdown there's not as many
componenttext: This is Steve. I would just add as far as the past quarter is concerned. Remember that in the Fed business also, we have contracts that in existence today. We own the contract and what we are seeing I think a little bit in the slowdown there's not as many POS as perhaps people had anticipated we will receive. I think it's tied more to the fiscal situation in the United States than it is to anything else.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes and I think on the question of VNX in general, the VNX has not been -- the VNX itself has not been much of a change in the dynamic in many accounts. The VNX E in terms of EMC's channels is something that we've seen more of. Certainly if you look at th
componenttext: Yes and I think on the question of VNX in general, the VNX has not been -- the VNX itself has not been much of a change in the dynamic in many accounts. The VNX E in terms of EMC's channels is something that we've seen more of. Certainly if you look at the performance of our volume segments clearly, that's been the strong as part of our portfolio. So I think it won't slow us down much. But nonetheless, I'd say that VNX E is something that we see particularly because of the channel push. And I think that's been something that's generated more discussion within NetApp and actually VNX itself. I think the VNX itself I think  has inflicted on Dell what it has inflicted on NetApp.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Just one last thing before we wrap up is I wanted to bring up that we are quite aware of a number of press articles about NetApp products being deployed in Syria by our systems integrator named Doria. And the one thing I want to be ve
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Just one last thing before we wrap up is I wanted to bring up that we are quite aware of a number of press articles about NetApp products being deployed in Syria by our systems integrator named Doria. And the one thing I want to be very, very clear about is I want to assure the people on the call, our customers, our partners, our employees that we absolutely do not support the sale of that equipment to Syria. I'm not here to suggest that we found a legal way to achieve an objective to sell products to a banned country. We have no intention of doing that and we adjusted the store those that is in a baned country as anybody else. The other thing is that NetApp produces storage products. We don't produce the applications that are being talked about in this particular article. And our products have been deployed in this solution and in a very generic way. And NetApp has not produced this application or participated in its development at all. 
And the last thing I probably want to point out is that NetApp has proactively reached out to the government. We offered a full assistance in reviewing the matter, sharing any information that we have about the situation and ultimately get to the facts. At this point, we don't know whether the story is true or acting as if it were and taken all the appropriate precautions. So I can assure you that this is the situation that we do not actively seek out. We did not choose to sell to the Syrian government. We did not deal with the Syrian government and we're not looking a way to circumvent U.S. sale to the Syrian government. We have no interest in providing a product to a banned country. I just want to measure that's clear. So with that I would like to thank you for your time today and your interest at NetApp and we'll see you all in 90 days.
